sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Manifest Destiny. Westward Expansion (1840s). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Samuel, age 16, on Oregon Trail, 1846.

I'm Samuel, sixteen, and our family has been on the Oregon Trail for six months. We left Independence, Missouri in the spring of 1846 with everything we owned packed into a covered wagon. Two thousand miles of prairie, mountains, rivers, and desert separate us from Oregon's Willamette Valley. The journey is harder than anyone imagined.
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Samuel, sixteen, and our family has been on the Oregon Trail for six months.

sections.narration: But the land isn't empty. We've passed through territories of the Pawnee, Sioux, Shoshone, and dozens of other Native nations. They watch our wagon trains from hills, sometimes trading with us, sometimes just observing. We're crossing their homeland without permission, hunting their buffalo, using their water, cutting their trees for firewood.

Oregon itself is disputed territory. Britain and America both claim it through competing treaties and exploration. The boundary hasn't been settled. Some Americans demand all of Oregon up to the 54°40' north latitude—the southern border of Russian Alaska.

After six months, we finally reach Oregon's Willamette Valley. The land is beautiful—green, fertile, watered by rain. We claim 640 acres under Oregon's provisional land laws. It's ours if we farm it and improve it.
sections.key_takeaway: After six months, we finally reach Oregon's Willamette Valley.

sections.narration: Manifest Destiny has given America vast new territory. Oregon, Texas, and soon California and the Southwest will add millions of acres to the nation. Americans are flooding west, building farms, towns, eventually states. The nation is growing wealthy and powerful.
visuals: Chapter title: The Cost of Destiny
sections.key_takeaway: Manifest Destiny has given America vast new territory.
